Follow these 6 steps in order for the most efficient batch prep workflow. This week features Asian-inspired flavors with a focus on crispy tofu and flavorful sauces.
. This is your base for all 14 meals. Let it cool.
Use a rice cooker set to "keep warm" while you prep other ingredients. Brown rice takes longer than white rice, so start this first to stay on schedule.
Press, cube, and toss tofu with cornstarch. Pan-fry, bake, or air-fry until crispy. Set aside.
Press tofu for at least 30 minutes to remove excess moisture - this is the secret to crispy tofu! Toss with cornstarch just before cooking for maximum crispiness.
Mince all garlic/ginger. Slice all green onions, peppers, etc. Blanch all green beans.
Blanch green beans for 2-3 minutes in boiling water, then shock in ice water. This preserves their bright green color and crisp-tender texture throughout the week.
Make all 4 sauces in separate, labeled jars so they are ready to go.
Gochujang-based sauces benefit from sitting for 15-30 minutes - the flavors meld and intensify. Mix these first while you prep other ingredients.
Work one recipe at a time. Cook the protein, add veggies and sauce. Portion over 1 cup of rice per container.
For bibimbap bowls, keep components slightly separated in the container - rice on bottom, protein and veggies on top. This prevents sogginess and makes reheating more even.
Let all hot meals cool 30-45 mins before lidding. Stack and refrigerate.
Place containers on a cooling rack for better air circulation. Once cool, stack in the fridge with oldest meals in front for easy "first in, first out" rotation.
Remove excess moisture by pressing tofu for 30+ minutes. Use a tofu press or wrap in paper towels with a heavy pan on top.
Asian stir-fries benefit from high heat. Preheat your pan until a drop of water sizzles immediately.
Have all ingredients prepped, sauces mixed, and proteins ready before you start cooking. Stir-fries cook fast!
Use containers with dividers for bibimbap bowls to keep components separated and fresh.
: Start rice immediately and let it work while you prep everything else
: Cook all tofu at once in the oven or air fryer (more hands-off than pan-frying)
: Blanch all green beans together, then shock in ice water
: All 4 sauces can be mixed and stored while other prep happens
: Store cooked meals in airtight containers for up to 5-7 days
: Store crispy tofu separately if possible and add just before eating for best texture
: Cooked brown rice stores well and reheats beautifully with a splash of water
: Keep bibimbap components slightly separated to maintain texture variety
Asian-inspired batch cooking workflow with tofu prep and vibrant stir-fries
